description:
Resettlement Administartion photograph
Many farmers are abandoning their homes and moving into dugouts near towns, to become eligible for drought relief. Grassy Butte, North Dakota
text: As Rothstein traveled on behalf of the Resettlement Administration during the Dust Bowl years, a period of time when dust storms and drought severely damaged the ecology and economy of the Great Plains, he captured the existence of those living in poverty. Rothstein documented the mass exodus of families abandoning their homes, many opting to live in “dugouts” -- small, dirt floor dwellings set entirely or partially underground often featuring small wooden structures erected around their openings.
title: Many farmers are abandoning their homes and moving into dugouts near towns, to become eligible for drought relief. Grassy Butte, North Dakota
